He ſaluted me, and I him: I aſked him from whence he came, and whither he would? he anſwered that he had come from Venice, then from Padua, nowe was going to Ferrara, and ſo to his countrey, whiche is Scienna: As ſoone as I knewe him to be a Sceneſe, ſodenly lifting vp mine eyes, (as it were with an admiration) I ſayd vnto him, are you a Sceneſe, and come to Farrara? why not, ſayde he: quoth I (, halfe and more with a trembling voyce) know you the daunger that ſhould enſue if you be knowne in Ferrara to be a Sceneſe? he more than halfe amaſed, deſired me earneſtly to tell him what I ment.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I vnderſtande not wherto this tendeth.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I beléeue you: but harken to me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Go too then.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I anſwered him in this ſorte: Gentleman, bycauſe I haue heretofore founde very curteous entertaynement in your countrey, (béeing a ſtudēt there,) I accompt my ſelf as it were bounde to a Sceneſe: and therefore if I knewe of any miſhappe towards any of that countrey, God forbid but I ſhould diſcloſe it: and I maruell that you knewe not of the iniurie that your countreymen offered this other day to the Embaſſadours of Counte Hercules.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: What tales he telleth me: what appertayne theſe to me?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: If you will harken a whyle, you ſhall finde them no tales, but that they appertayne to you more than you thinke for.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Foorth.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p:
I tolde him further, theſe Ambaſſadoures of Counte Hercules had dyuers Mules, Waggons, and Charettes, ladē with diuers coſtly iewels, gorgeous furniture, & other things which they caried as preſents, (paſſing that way) to the king of Naples: the which were not only ſtayd in Sciene by the officers whom you cal Cuſtomers, but ſerched, ranſacked, toſſed & turned, & in the end exacted for tribute, as
if they had bene the goods of a meane marchaunt.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Whither the diuell wil he? is it poſſible that this geare appertaine any thing to my cauſe? I finde neither head nor foote in it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: O how impaciēt you are: I pray you ſtay a while.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Go to yet a while then.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I procéeded, that vpon theſe cauſes the Duke ſent his Chauncelor to declare the caſe vnto the Senate there, of whome he had the moſte vncurteous anſwere that euer was heard: whervpon he was ſo enraged with all of that countrey, that for reuenge he had ſworne to ſpoyle as many of them as euer ſhould come to Ferara, and to ſende them home in their dublet and their hoſe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And I pray thée how couldeſt thou vpon the ſudden deuiſe or imagine ſuche a lye? and to what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: You ſhall heare by and by a thing as fitte for our purpoſe, as any could haue happened.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I would fayne heare you conclude.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: You would fayne leape ouer the ſtile, before you come at the hedge: I woulde you had heard me, and ſéene the geſtures that I enforced to make him beléeue this.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I beléeue you, for I knowe you can counterfet wel.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Further I ſayde, the duke had charged vpon great penalties, that the Inholders and vitlers ſhoulde bring worde dayly of as many Sceneſes as came to their houſes. The gentleman béeing (as I geſſed at the firſt) a mā of ſmal ſapientia, when he heard theſe newes, would haue turned his horſe an other way.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: By likelyhoode he was not very wiſe when hée would beleeue that of his countrey, which if it had bene true euery man muſt néedes haue knowen it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Why not? when he had not béene in his countrey for a moneth paſte, and I tolde him this had hapned within theſe ſeuen dayes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Belike he was of ſmall experience.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I thinke, of as litle as may be: but beſte of all for our purpoſe, and good aduenture it was, that I mette with ſuch an one. Now harken I pray you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Make an ende I pray thée.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: He, as I ſay, when he hard theſe words, would haue turned the bridle: and I fayning a countenance as though I were ſomewhat penſiue and carefull for him, pauſed a while, & after with a great ſighe ſaide to him: Gentleman, for the curteſie that (as I ſaid) I haue found in your countrey, & bicauſe your affaires ſhall be the better diſpatched, I will finde the meanes to lodge you in my houſe, and you ſhal ſay to euery mā, that you are a Sicilian of Cathanea, your name Philogano, father to me that am in déede of that countrey and citie, called here Eroſtrato. And I (to pleaſure you) will (during your abode here) do you reuerence as you were my father.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Out vpon me, what a groſſe hedded foole am I? now I perceiue whereto this tale tendeth.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Well, and how like you of it?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Indifferently, but one thing I doubt.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Marie, that when he hath bene here twoo or thrée dayes, he ſhal heare of euery man that there is no ſuch thing betwene the Duke and the Towne of Sciene.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: As for that let me alone, I doe entertaine and will entertaine him ſo well, that within theſe two or thrée daies I will diſcloſe vnto him all the whole matter, and doubte not but to bring him in for performance of as muche as I haue promiſed to Damon: for what hurte can it be to him, when he ſhall binde a ſtrange name and not his owne?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: What, thinke you he will be entreated to ſtande bounde for a dower of two thouſand Ducates by the yéere?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Yea why not, (if it were ten thouſande) as long as he is not in déede the man that is bound?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p:
Well, if it be ſo, what ſhall we be the néerer to our
purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Why? when we haue done as muche as we can, how can we doe any more?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And where haue you left him?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: At the Inne, bicauſe of his horſes: he and his men ſhall lie in my houſe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Why brought you him not with you?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I thought better to vſe your aduiſe firſt.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Well, goe take him home, make him all the chéere you can, ſpare for no coſt, I will alowe it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Content, looke where he commeth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Is this he? goe méete him, by my trouthe he lookes euen lyke a good ſoule, he that fiſheth for him, mighte bée ſure to catche a cods heade: I will reſt here a while to diſcipher him.

div.stage: Eroſtrato eſpieth the Sceneſe and goeth towards him: Dulipo ſtandeth aſide.

div.head: Scena. ij.
div.stage: The SCENESE. PAQVETTO & PETRVCIO his ſeruāts. EROSTRATO.
div.p: HE that trauaileth in this worlde paſſeth by many perilles.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: An other ſupoſe.You ſaye true ſir, if the boate had bene a little more laden this morning at the ferrie, wée had bene all drowned, for I thinke, there are none of vs that could haue ſwomme.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: I ſpeake not of that.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: O you meane the foule waye that we had ſince wée came from this Padua, I promiſe you, I was afraide twice or thrice, that your mule would haue lien faſt in the mire.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Ieſu, what a blockehead thou art, I ſpeake of the perill we are in preſently ſince we came into this citie.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
A great peril I promiſe you, that we were no ſooner
ariued, but you founde a frende that brought you from the Inne, and lodged you in his owne houſe.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Yea marie, God rewarde the gentle yong man that we mette, for elſe we had bene in a wiſe caſe by this time.A dottiſh ſupoſe. But haue done with theſe tales, and take you héede, & you alſo ſirra, take héede that none of you ſaie we be Sceneſes, and remember that you call me Philogano of Cathanca.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Sure I ſhal neuer remember theſe outlādiſh words, I could well remember Haccanea.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: I ſay, Cathanea, and not Haecanea, with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Let another name it then when néede is, for I ſhall neuer remember it.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Then holde thy peace, and take héede thou name not Scene.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Howe ſay you, if I faine my ſelfe dum as I did once in the houſe of Criſobolus?

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Doe as thou thinkeſt beſt: but looke where commeth the gentleman whom we are ſo much bounde vnto.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Welcome, my deare father Philogano.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Gramercie my good ſonne Eroſtrato.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: That is well ſaide, be mindefull of your toung, for theſe Ferareſes be as craftie as the Deuill of hell.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: No, no, be you ſure we will doe as you haue bidden vs.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: For if you ſhould name Scene they would ſpoile you immediatly, and turne you out of the towne, with more ſhame, than I woulde ſhoulde befall you for a thouſande Crownes.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: I warant you, I was giuing thē warning as I came to you, and I doubt not but they will take good héede.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Yea and truſt not the ſeruauntes of my houſholde to far, for they are Ferareſes all, and neuer knew my father, nor came neuer in Sicilia: this is my houſe, will it pleaſe you to goe in? I will follow.

stage.hi: Dulipo tarieth and eſpieth the Doctor comming in with his man.

div.head: Scena. iij.
div.p: THis geare hath had no euill beginning, if it continue ſo and fall to happie ende. But is not this the ſilly Doctor with the ſide bonet, the doting foole, that dare preſume to become a ſuter to ſuch a péerleſſe Paragone? O how couetouſneſſe doth blind the common ſort of men. Damon more deſirous of the dower, than mindfull of his gentle & gallant daughter, hath determined to make him his Sonne in law, who for his age may be his father in law: and hath greater reſpect to the abundance of goods, than to his owne naturall childe. He beareth well in minde to fill his owne purſe, but he litle remembreth that his daughters purſe ſhalbe continually emptie, vnleſſe Maiſter Doctour fill it with double ducke egges. Alas: I ieſt and haue no ioy, I will ſtand here aſide and laugh a litle at this lobcocke.
div.stage: Dulippo eſpieth the Doctor and his man comming.

div.head: Scena. iiij.
div.stage: CARION the doctors man. CLEANDER. DVLIPO.
div.p: MAiſter, what the Diuel meane you to goe ſéeke gueſtes at this time of the day? the Maiors officers haue dined ere this time, which are alway the laſt in the market.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I come to ſéeke Paſiphilo, to the ende he may dine with mée.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: As though ſixe mouthes and the cat for the ſeuenth, bée not ſufficient to eate an harlotrie ſhotterell, a pennieworth of cheeſe, and halfe a ſcore ſpurlings: this is all the dainties you haue dreſſed for you and your familie.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ah gréedie gut, art thou afearde thou ſhalt want?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: I am afearde in déede, it is not the firſt time I haue founde it ſo.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Shall I make ſome ſporte with this gallant? what ſhall I ſay to him?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thou arte afearde belike that he will eate thée and the reſt.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Nay, rather that he will eate your mule, both heare and hyde.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Heare and hyde? and why not fleſh and all?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Bicauſe ſhe hath none. If ſhe had any fleſh, I thinke you had eaten hir your ſelfe by this time.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: She may thanke you then, for your good attendāce.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Nay ſhe may thanke you for your ſmall allowance.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: In faith now let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Holde thy peace drunken knaue, and eſpie me Paſiphilo.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Since I can doe no better, I will ſet ſuch a ſtaunce betwéene him and Paſiphilo, that all this towne ſhall not make them friendes.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Could you not haue ſent to ſéeke him, but you muſt come your ſelfe? ſurely you come for ſome other purpoſe, for if you would haue had Paſiphilo to dinner, I warant you he would haue taried here an houre ſince.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Holde thy peace, here is one of Damons ſeruaunts,An other ſupoſe. of him I ſhall vnderſtand where he is: good fellow art not thou one of Damons ſeruaunts?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yes ſir, at your knamandement.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Gramercie, tell me then, hath Paſiphilo bene there this day or no?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yes ſir, and I thinke he be there ſtill, ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What laugheſt thou?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: At a thing, that euery man may not laugh at.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Talke, that Paſiphilo had with my maſter this day.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What talke I pray thée?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I may not tell it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Doth it concerne me?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Nay I will ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Tell me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I can ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I woulde but knowe if it concerne mée, I pray thée tell mée.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I would tell you, if I were ſure you would not tell it againe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Beleue me I will kepe it cloſe: Carion giue vs leaue a litle, goe aſide.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: If my maiſter ſhoulde know that it came by me, I were better die a thouſand deaths.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He ſhall neuer know it, ſay on.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yea, but what aſſurance ſhall I haue?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I lay thée my faith and honeſtie in paune.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: A pretie paune, the fulkers will not lend you a farthing on it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yea, but amongſt honeſt mē it is more worth than golde.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yea marie ſir, but where be they? but will you néedes haue me tell it vnto you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yea I pray thée if it any thing appertaine to me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yes it is of you, and I would gladly tell it you, bicauſe I would not haue ſuche a man of worſhip ſo ſcorned by a villaine ribaulde.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I pray thée tell me then.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I will tell you ſo that you will ſweare neuer to tell it to Paſiphilo, to my maiſter, nor to any other bodie.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Surely it is ſome toye deuiſed to get ſome money of him.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I thinke I haue a booke here.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
If he knew him as well as I, he woulde neuer goe aboute it, for he may as ſoone get one of his téeth from his
iawes with a paire of pinchers, as a pennie out of his purſe with ſuch a conceite.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Here is a letter wil ſerue the turne: I ſweare to thée by the contents hereof neuer to diſcloſe it to any man.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I will tell you, I am ſorie to ſee how Paſiphilo doth abuſe you, perſwading you that alwayes he laboureth for you, where in déede, he lieth on my maiſter continually, as it were with tooth and naile for a ſtraunger, a ſcholer, borne in Sicilia they call him Roſcus or arſkiſſe, he hathe a madde name I can neuer hit vpon it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And thou reckneſt it as madly: is it not Eroſtrato?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: That ſame I ſhould neuer haue remembred it: and the villany ſpeaketh al the euill of you that can be deuiſed.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: To my maiſter, yea and to Polyneſta hirſelfe ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Is it poſſible, Ah ſlaue, and what ſaith he?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: More euill than I can imagine: that you are the miſerableſt and moſt nigardly man that euer was.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sayeth Paſiphilo ſo by me?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And that as often as he commeth to your houſe, he is like to die for hunger, you fare ſo well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That the Deuill take him elſe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And that you are the teſtieſt man, & moſte diuers to pleaſe in the whole worlde, ſo that he cannot pleaſe you vnleſſe he ſhould euen kill himſelfe with continuall paine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O deuiliſh tong.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Furthermore, that you cough continually and ſpit, ſo that a dogge cannot abide it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I neuer ſpitte nor coughe more than thus, vho, vho, and that but ſince I caughte this murre, but who is frée from it?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: You ſaye true ſir, yet further he ſayth, your arme holes ſtincke, your féete worſe than they, and your breathe worſt of all.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: If I quite him not for this geare.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And that you are burſten in the cods.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O villaine, he lieth, and if I were not in the ſtréete thou ſhouldeſt ſée them.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And he ſaith, that you deſire this yong gentle woman, as much for other mens pleaſure as for your owne.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What meaneth he by that?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Peraduenture that by hir beautie, you woulde entice many yong men to your houſe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yong men? to what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Nay, geſſe you that.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Is it poſſible that Paſiphilo ſpeaketh thus of me?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yea, and much more.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And doth Damon beléeue him?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yea, more than you would thinke: in ſuch ſort, that long ere this, he woulde haue giuen you a flat repulſe, but Paſiphilo intreated him to continue you a ſuter for his aduantage.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How for his aduantage?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Marie, that during your ſute he might ſtill haue ſome rewarde for his great paines.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He ſhall haue a rope, and yet that is more than he deſerueth: I had thought to haue giuen him theſe hoſe when I had worne them a litle nearer, but he ſhall haue a. &c.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: In good faith ſir, they were but loſte on him. Will you any thing elſe with me ſir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, I haue heard to much of thée already.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Then I will take my leaue of you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Farewell, but tell me, may I not know thy name?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Sir, they call me Foule fall you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: An ill fauored name by my trouthe: arte thou this countrey man?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: No ſir, I was borne by a caſtle mē cal Scabbe catch you: fare you well ſir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Farewel. Oh God how haue I bene abuſed? what a
ſpokeſman? what a meſſanger had I prouided?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why ſir, will you tarie for Paſiphilo till we die for hunger?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Trouble me not, that the Deuill take you both.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Theſe newes what ſo euer they be, like him not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Art thou ſo hungrie yet? I pray to God thou be neuer ſatiſfied.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: By the maſſe no more I ſhal as long as I am your ſeruaunt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Goe with miſchaunce.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yea, and a miſchiefe to you, and to al ſuch couetous wretches.

div.head: Scena. j.
div.stage: DALIO the cooke. CRAPINE the lackie. EROSTRATO, DVLIPO.
div.p: BY that time we come to the houſe, I truſte that of theſe xx. egges in the baſket we ſhall find but very few whole. But it is a folly to talke to him. What the deuill, wilt thou neuer lay that ſticke out of thy hande? he fighteth with the dogges, beateth the beares, at euery thing in the ſtreate he findeth occaſion to tarie: if he ſpie a ſlipſtring by the waye ſuch another as himſelf, a Page, a Lackie or a dwarfe, the deuill of hell cannot holde him in chaynes, but he will be doing with him: I cannot goe two ſteppes, but I muſte looke backe for my yonker: goe to halter ſicke, if you breake one egge I may chance breake, &c.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What will you breake? your noſe in mine &c?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Ah beaſt.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: If I be a beaſt, yet I am no horned beaſt.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Is it euen ſo? is the winde in that doore? If I were vnloden I would tel you whether I be a horned beaſt or no.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You are alway laden either with wine or with ale.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Ah ſpitefull boy, ſhall I ſuffer him?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ah cowardely beaſt, dareſt thou ſtrike and ſay neuer a woorde?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Well, my maiſter ſhall know of this géere, either he ſhall redreſſe it, or he ſhall loſe one of vs.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Eroſtra. & Du. ex improuiſo.Tel him the worſt thou canſt by me.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: What noiſe, what a rule is this?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Marie ſir, he ſtriketh mée bicauſe I tell him of his ſwearing.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: The villaine lieth deadly, he reuiles me bicauſe I bid him make haſt.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Holla: no more of this. Dalio, doe you make in a readineſſe thoſe Pigeons, ſtock Doues, and alſo the breaſt of Veale: and let your veſſell be as cleare as glaſſe againſt I returne, that I may tell you which I will haue roaſted, & which boyled. Crapine, ſay downe that baſket and followe me. Oh that I coulde tell where to finde Paſiphilo, but looke where he commeth that can tell me of him.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Dulipo is eſpied by Eroſtrato.What haue you done with Philogano your father?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I haue left him within, I would faine ſpeake with Paſiphilo, can you tell me where he is?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: He dined this day with my maiſter, but whether he went from thence I know not, what would you with him?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I woulde haue him goe tell Damon that Philogano my father is come and ready to make aſſurance of as much as he wil require. Now ſhall I teach maiſter doctor a ſchole point, he trauaileth to none other end but to catche Cornua, and he ſhall haue them, for as old as he is, and as many ſubtilties as he hath learned in the law, he can not goe beyond me one ace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: O déere friend, goe thy wayes ſéeke Paſiphilo, finde him out, and conclude ſomewhat to our contentation.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: But where ſhall I finde him?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: At the feaſts if there be any, or elſe in the market with the poulters or the fiſhmongers.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: What ſhould he doe with them?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Mary he watcheth whoſe Caters bie the beſt meat. If any bie a fat Capon, a good breaſt of Veale, freſh Samon or any ſuche good diſhe, he followeth to the houſe, and either with ſome newes, or ſome ſtale ieſt he will be ſure to make himſelfe a geaſt.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: In faith, and I will ſéeke there for him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Then muſte you néedes finde him, and when you haue done I will make you laughe.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Whereat?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: At certaine ſport I made to day with maſter doctor.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: And why not now?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: No it aſketh further leyſure, I pray thée diſpatche, and finde out Paſiphilo that honeſt man.

div.head: Scena. ij.
div.p:
THis amorous cauſe that hāgeth in cōtrouerſie betwene Domine doctor & me, may be compared to thē that play at primero: of whō ſome one peraduēture ſhal léeſe a great ſum of money before he win one ſtake, & at laſt halfe in anger ſhal ſet vp his reſt: win it: & after that another, another, & another, till at laſt he draw the moſt part of the money to his heape: ye other by litle & litle ſtil diminiſhing his reſt, til at laſt he be come as néere the brinke, as earſt ye other was: yet again peraduēture fortune ſmiling on him, he ſhal as it were by péece meale, pull out the guts of his fellows bags, & bring him barer than he himſelfe was tofore, & ſo in play continue ſtil, (fortune fauoring now this way, now yt way) til at laſt the one of thē is left with as many croſſes as God hath brethren. O howe often haue I thoughte my ſelfe ſure of the vpper hande herein? but I triumphed before the victorie. And then how ofte againe haue I thoughte the fielde loſte? Thus haue I béene toſſed nowe ouer, nowe vnder,
euen as fortune liſt to whirle the whéele, neither ſure to winne nor certayne to looſe the wager. And this practiſe that nowe my ſeruaunte hath deuiſed, although hitherto it hath not ſucceeded amiſſe, yet can I not count my ſelfe aſſured of it: for I feare ſtill that one miſchance or other wyll come and turne it topſie turuie. But looke where my mayſter commeth.
div.stage: Damon comming in, eſpieth Dulipo and calleth him.

div.head: Scena. iij.
div.stage: DAMON. DVLIPO. NEVOLA, and two mo ſeruants.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Here ſir.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Go in and bid Neuola and his fellowes come hither that I may tell them what they ſhall goe about, and go you into my ſtudie: there vpon the ſhelfe you ſhall find a roule of writings which Iohn of the Deane made to my Father, when he ſolde him the Grange ferme, endorced with bothe their names: bring it hither to me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: It ſhall be done ſir.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Go, I wil prepare other maner of writings for you thā you are aware of. O fooles that truſt any mā but themſelues now adaies: oh ſpiteful fortune, thou doeſt me wrong I thinke, that from the depth of Hell pitte thou haſte ſente mée this ſeruaunt to be the ſubuerſion of me and all mine. Come hither ſirs,The ſeruants come in. and heare what I ſhal ſay vnto you: go into my ſtudie, where you ſhall finde Dulipo, ſtep to him all at once, take him and (with a corde that I haue laide on the table for the nonce) bind him hande and foote, carie him into the dungeon vnder the ſtayres, make faſte the dore & bring me the key, it hangeth by vpon a pin on the wall. Diſpatche and doe this geare as priuily as you can: and thou Neuola come hither to me againe with ſpéede.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Well I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Alas how ſhall I be reuenged of this extreme deſpite? if I puniſhe my ſeruant according to his diueliſhe deſerts, I ſhall heape further cares vpon mine owne head: for to ſuche deteſtable offences no puniſhment can ſéeme ſufficient, but onely death, and in ſuch caſes it is not lawful for a man to be his owne caruer. The lawes are ordeyned, and officers appoynted to miniſter iuſtice for the redreſſe of wrongs: and if to the poteſtates I complayne me, I ſhall publiſhe mine owne reproche to the worlde. Yea, what ſhould it preuayle me to vſe all the puiniſhments that can be deuiſed? the thing once done can not be vndone. My daughter is defloured, and I vtterly diſhoneſted: how can I then wype that blot off my browe? and on whome ſhall I ſéeke reuenge? Alas, alas I my ſelfe haue bene the cauſe of all theſe cares, and haue deſerued to beare the puniſhment of all theſe miſhappes. Alas, I ſhould not haue committed my deareſt darling in cuſtodie to ſo careleſſe a creaſure as this olde Nurſe: for we ſee by common proofe, that theſe olde women be either péeuiſhe, or pitifull: either eaſily enclined to euill, or quickly corrupted with bribes and rewards. O wife, my good wife (that nowe lyeſt colde in the graue) now may I well bewayle the wante of thée, and mourning nowe may I bemone that I miſſe thée: if thou hadſt liued (ſuche was thy gouernement of the leaſt things) that thou wouldeſt prudently haue prouided for the preſeruation of this pearle. A coſtly iewell may I well accompte hir, that hath béen my chéefe comforte in youth, and is nowe become the coroſiue of mine age. O Polyneſta, full euill haſt thou requited the clemencie of thy carefull father: and yet to excuſe thée giltleſſe before God, and to condemne thée giltie before the worlde, I can count none other but my wretched ſelfe the caytife and cauſer of all my cares. For of al the dueties that are requiſite in humane lyfe, onely obedience is by the parents to be required of the childe: where on ye other
ſide the parents are bound, firſt to beget them, then to bring thē foorth, after to nouriſh them, to preſerue them from bodily perils in the cradle, from daunger of ſoule by godly education, to matche them in conſort enclined to vertue, too baniſh them all ydle and wanton companie, to allow them ſufficiente for their ſuſtentation, to cut off exceſſe the open gate of ſinne, ſeldome or neuer to ſmile on them vnleſſe it be to their encouragement in vertue, and finally, to prouide them mariages in time cōuenient, leſt (neglected of vs) they learne to ſette either to much or to litle by thēſelues. Fiue yeares are paſt ſince I might haue maried hir, when by cō tinuall excuſes I haue prolonged it to my owne perdition. Alas, I ſhoulde haue conſidered, ſhe is a collop of my owne fleſh: what ſhold I think to make hir a princeſſe? Alas alas, a poore kingdome haue I now caught to endowe hir with: It is too true, that of all ſorowes this is the head ſource and chiefe fountaine of all furies: the goods of the world are incertain, the gaines to be reioyced at, and the loſſe not greatly to be lamented: only the children caſt away, cutteth the parents throate with the knife of inward care, which knife will kill me ſurely, I make none other accompte.

div.stage: Damons ſeruants come to him againe.

div.head: Scena. iiij.
div.p: SIr, we haue done as you hadde vs, and here is the key.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, go then Neuola and ſéeke maſter Caſteling the iayler, he dwelleth by S. Antonies gate, deſire him too lend me a paire of the fetters he vſeth for his priſoners, and come againe quickly.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Well ſir.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Heare you, if he aſke what I would do with them, ſay you cā not tell, and tell neither him nor any other, what
is become of Dulipo.
Damon goeth out.

I warant you ſir. Fye vpon the Deuill,An other ſuppoſe. it is a thing almoſt vnpoſſible for a man nowe a dayes to handle money, but the mettal will ſticke on his fingers: I maruelled alway at this fellowe of mine Dulipo, that of the wages he receiued, he could maintaine himſelfe ſo brauely apparelled, but nowe I perceiue the cauſe, he had the diſburſing and receit of all my maſters affaires, the keys of the granair, Dulippo here, Dulippo there, fauoure with my maiſter, in fauoure with his daughter, what woulde you more, he was Magiſter factotum: he was as fine as the Cruſadoe, and wée ſilly wretches as courſe as canuas: wel, behold what it is come to in the ende, he had bin better to haue done leſſe.Paſi. ſubito & improuiſo venit.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Thou ſaiſt true Neuola, he hath done to much in déed.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: From whence commeſt thou in the deuils name?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Out of the ſame houſe thou cameſt from, but not out of the ſame dore.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: We had thought thou hadſt bene gone long ſince.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: When I aroſe from the table, I felte a rumbling in my belly, whiche made me runne to the ſtable, and there I fell on ſléepe vppon the ſtrawe, and haue line there euer ſince: And thou whether goeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: My maſter hath ſent me on an errand in great haſt.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Whether I pray thée?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Nay I may not tell: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
As though I néede any further inſtructions: O God what newes I heard euē now, as I lay in the ſtable: O good Eroſtrato and pore Cleander, An other ſuppoſe. that haue ſo earneſtly ſtrouen for this damſel, happie is he that can get hir I promiſe you, he ſhall be ſure of mo than one at a clap that catcheth hir, eyther Adam or Eue within hir belie. Oh God, how men may be deceiued in a woman? who wold haue beléeued the contrary but that ſhe had bin a virgin? aſke the neighbours and you ſhall heare very good report of hir: marke hir behauiors & you would haue iudged hir very maydenly: ſeldome ſéene
abroade but in plac • of prayer, and there very deuout, and no gaſer at outwarde ſightes, no blaſer of hir beautie aboue in the windowes, no ſtale at the doore for the bypaſſers: you would haue thought hir a holy yong woman. But muche good doe it Domine Doctor, hee ſhall be ſure to lacke no CORNE in a deare yere, whatſoeuer he haue with hir elſe: I beſhrewe me if I let the mariage any way. But is not this the old ſcabbed queane that I heard diſcloſing all this géere to hir maſter, as I ſtoode in the ſtable ere nowe? it is ſhée. Whither goeth Pſiteria?

div.head: Scena. v.
div.p: TO a Goſſip of myne héereby.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What? to tattle of the goodly ſtirre that thou keptſt concerning Polyneſta.

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: No no: but how knew you of that géere?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You tolde me.

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: I? when did I tell you?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Euen now when you tolde it to Damon, I both ſawe you and heard you, though you ſaw not me: a good parte I promiſe you, to accuſe the poore wenche, kill the olde man with care, ouer and beſides the daunger you haue brought Dulipo and the Nurſſe vnto, and many moe, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: In déed I was to blame, but not ſo much as you think.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: And how not ſo muche? did I not heare you tell?

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p:
Yes, But I will tell you how it came to paſſe: I haue knowen for a great while, that this Dulipo and Polyneſta haue lyen togither, and all by the meanes of the nurſe: yet I held my peace, and neuer tolde it. Now this other day the Nurſſe ſell on ſcolding with me, and twyce or thryce called me drunken olde whore, and ſuche names that it was too badde: and I called hir baude, and tolde hir that I
knew well enoughe howe often ſhe had brought Dulipo to Polyneſtas bed: yet all this while I thought not that anye body had heard me, but it befell cleane contrarye: for my maiſter was on the other ſide of the wall, and heard all our talke, where vpon he ſent for me, and forced me to confeſſe all that you heard.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: And why wouldeſt thou tell him? I woulde not for. &c.

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: Well, if I had thought my maiſter would haue taken it ſo, he ſhould rather haue killed me.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Why? how could he take it?

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: Alas, it pitieth me to ſée the poore yong woman how ſhe wéepes, wailes, and teares hir heare: not eſteming hir owne life halfe ſo deare as ſhe doth poore Dulipos: and hir father, he wéepes on the other ſide, that it would pearce an hart of ſtone with pitie: but I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Go that the gunne pouder conſume thée olde trotte.

div.head: Scena. j.
div.p:
WHat ſhall I doe? Alas what remedie ſhall I finde for my ruefull eſtate? what eſcape, or what excuſe may I now deuiſe to ſhifte ouer our ſubtile ſuppoſes? for though to this day I haue vſurped the name of my maiſter, and that without checke or controll of any man, now ſhal I be openly diſcyphred, and that in the ſight of euery man: now ſhal it openly be knowen, whether I be Eroſtrato the gentleman, or Dulipo the ſeruaunt. We haue hitherto played our parts in abuſing others: but nowe commeth the man that wil not be abuſed, the right Philogano the right father of the right Eroſtrato: going to ſeke Paſiphilo, and hearing that he was at the water gate, beholde I eſpied my fellowe Litio, and
by and by my olde maiſter Philogano ſetting forth his firſt ſtep on land: I to fuge and away hither as faſt as I could to bring word to the right Eroſtrato, of his right father Philogano, that to ſo ſodaine a miſhap ſome ſubtile ſhift might be vpō the ſodaine deuiſed. But what can be imagined to ſerue the turne, although we had monethes reſpite to beate oure braines about it, ſince we are commōly knowen, at the leaſt ſuppoſed in this towne, he for Dulipo, a ſlaue & ſeruant to Damon, & I for Eroſtrato a gentleman & a ſtudent? But beholde, runne Crapine to yonder olde woman before ſhe get within the doores, & deſire hir to call out Dulipo: but heare you? if ſhe aſke who would ſpeake with him, ſaye thy ſelfe and none other.
div.stage: Eroſtrato eſpieth Pſiteria comming, and ſendeth his lackey to hir.

div.head: Scena. ij.
div.p: HOneſt woman, you goſſip, thou rotten whore, heareſt thou not olde witche?

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: A rope ſtretche your yong bones, either you muſte liue to be as old as I, or be hanged while you are yong.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I pray thée loke if Dulipo be within.

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: Yes that he is I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Deſire him then to come hither and ſpeake a word with me, he ſhall not tarie.

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: Content your ſelfe, he is otherwiſe occupied.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yet tell him ſo gentle girle.

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: I tell you he is buſie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why is it ſuch a matter to tell him ſo, thou crooked Crone?

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: A rope ſtretche you marie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: A pockes eate you marie.

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: Thou wilt be hanged I warāt thée, if thou liue to it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And thou wilt be burnt I warant thée, if the canker conſume thée not.

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: If I come néere you hempſtring, I will teache you to ſing ſolfa.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Come on, and if I get a ſtone I will ſcare crowes with you.

sp.speaker: Pſ.
sp.p: Goe with a miſchiefe, I thinke thou be ſome deuill that woulde tempte me.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Crapine: heare you? come away, let hir goe with a vengeance, why come you not? Alas loke where my maiſter Philogano commeth: what ſhall I doe? where ſhall I hide me? he ſhall not ſée me in theſe clothes, nor before I haue ſpoken with the right Eroſtrato.

div.stage: Eroſtrato eſpyeth Phylogano commming, and runneth about to hide him.

div.head: Scena. iij.
div.stage: PHILOGANO. FERRARESE the Inne keper. LITIO a ſeruant.
div.p: HOneſt man it is euen ſo: be you ſure there is no loue to be compared like the loue of the parents towards their children. It is not long ſince I thought that a very waightie matter ſhoulde not haue made me come out of Sicilia, and yet now I haue taken this tedious toyle and trauaile vpon me, only to ſée my ſonne, and to haue him home with me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: By my faith ſir, it hath ben a great trauaile in dede, and to much for one of your age.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yea be you ſure: I came in companie with certaine gentlemen of my countrey, who had affaires to diſpatche as far as to Aneona, from thence by water too Rauenna, and from Rauenna hither, continually againſt the tide.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Yea & I think yt you had but homly lodging by yt way.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
The worſt yt euer man had: but that was nothing to the ſtirre that ye ſerchers kept with me when I came aborde ye ſhip: Ieſus how often they vntruſſed my male, & ranſaked
a litle capcaſe that I had, toſſed & turned al that was within it, ſerched my boſome, yea my breeches, yt I aſſure you I thought they would haue flayed me to ſearche betwene the fell and the fleſhe for fardings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sure I haue heard no leſſe, and that the marchants bobbe them ſomtimes, but they play the knaues ſtill.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yea be you well aſſured, ſuche an office is the inheritance of a knaue, and an honeſt man will not meddle with it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Wel, this paſſage ſhal ſeme pleaſant vnto you whē you ſhall finde your childe in health and well: but I praye you ſir why did you not rather ſend for him into Sicilia, than to come your ſelfe, ſpecially ſince you had none other buſineſſe? peraduenture you had rather endanger your ſelfe by this noyſome iourney, than hazard to drawe him from his ſtudie.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Nay, that was not the matter, for I had rather haue him giue ouer his ſtudie altogither and come home.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Why? if you minded not to make him learned, to what ende did you ſend him hither at the firſt?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I will tell you: when he was at home he did as moſt yong men doe, he played many mad prankes and did many things that liked me not very well: and I thinking, that by that time he had ſene the worlde, he would learne to know himſelfe better, exhorted him to ſtudie, and put in his electiō what place he would go to. At the laſt he came hither, and I thinke he was ſcarce here ſo ſone as I felt the want of him, in ſuche ſorte, as from that day to this I haue paſſed fewe nightes without teares. I haue written to him very often that he ſhoulde come home, but continually he refuſed ſtil, beſeching me to continue his ſtudie, wherein he doubted not (as he ſaid) but to profite greatly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: In dede he is very much commended of al men, and ſpecially of the beſt reputed ſtudentes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
I am glad he hath not loſt his time, but I care not
greatly for ſo much knowledge. I would not be without the ſighte of hym againe ſo long, for all the learning in the worlde. I am olde nowe, and if God ſhoulde call mée in his abſence, I promiſe you I thinke it woulde driue me into diſperation.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: It is commendable in a man to loue his childrē but to be ſo tender ouer them is more womanlike?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Well, I confeſſe it is my faulte: and yet I will tell you another cauſe of my comming hither, more waightie than this. Diuers of my countrey haue bene here ſince hée came hither, by whome I haue ſente vnto him, and ſome of thē haue bene thrice, ſome foure or fiue times at his houſe, and yet could neuer ſpeake with him. I feare he applies his ſtudie ſo, that he will not léeſe the minute of an houre from his booke. What, alas, he might yet talke with his countrymen for a while: he is a yong man, tenderly brought vp, and if he fare thus cōtinually night & day at his booke, it may be enough to driue him into a freneſie.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: In dede, enough were as good as a feaſt. Loe you ſir here is your ſonne Eroſtratoes houſe, I will knocke.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yea, I pray you knocke.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: They heare not.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Knocke againe,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I thinke they be on ſlepe.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p: If this gate were your Grandefathers ſoule, you coulde not knocke more ſoftly, let me come: ho, ho, is there any body within?

div.stage: Dalio commeth to the wyndowe, and there maketh them anſwere.

div.head: Scena. iiij.
div.stage: DALIO the cooke. FERARESE the inholder. PHILOGANO. LITIO his man.
div.p: WHat deuill of hell is there? I thinke hée will breake the gates in péeces.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Marie ſir, we had thoughte you had béene on ſléepe within, and therefore we thought beſt to wake you: what doth Eroſtrato?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: He is not within.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Open the dore good fellow I pray thée.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: If you thinke to lodge here, you are deceiued I tell you, for here are gueſtes enowe already.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: A good fellow, and much for thy maiſter honeſty by our Ladie: and what gueſtes I pray thée?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Another ſuppoſe.Here is Philogano my maiſters father, lately come out of Sicilia.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakeſt truer thā thou arte aware of, he will be, by that time thou haſt opened the dore: open I pray thée hartily.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: It is a ſmall matter for me to open the dore, but here is no lodging for you, I tell you plaine, the houſe is full.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Of whome?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I tolde you: here is Philogano my maiſters father come from Cathanea.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And when came he?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: He came thrée houres ſince, or more, he alighted at the Aungell, and left his horſes there: afterwarde my maiſter brought him hither.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Good fellow, I thinke thou haſt good ſport to mocke mée.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay, I thinke you haue good ſporet to make me tary here, as though I haue nothing elſe to doe: I am matched with an vnrulye mate in the kitchin. I will goe looke to him another while.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I thinke he be drunken.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sure he ſemes ſo: ſée you not how redde he is about the gilles?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Abide fellow, what Philogano is it whome thou talkeſt of?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: An honeſt gentlemā, father to Eroſtrato my maiſter.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And where is he?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Here within.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: May we ſée him?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I thinke you may if you be not blind.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Go to, go tel him here is one wold ſpeake with him.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Mary that I will willingly doe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I can not tell what I ſhoulde ſay to this géere. Litio, what thinkeſt thou of it?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: I cannot tell you what I ſhoulde ſay ſir, the worlde is large and long,Another ſuppoſe. there maye be moe Philoganos and moe Eroſtratos than one, yea and moe Ferraras, moe Sicilias, and moe Cathaneas: peraduenture this is not that Ferrara whiche you ſent your ſonne vnto.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Peraduenture thou arte a foole, and he was another that anſwered vs euen now. But be you ſure honeſt man, that you miſtake not the houſe?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Nay, then god helpe, thinke you I knowe not Eroſtratos houſe? yes, and himſelfe alſo: I ſawe him here no longer ſince thā yeſterday. But here cōmes one that wil tell vs tydings of him, I like his countenaunce better than the others that anſwered at the windowe erewhile.

div.stage: Dalio draweth his hed in at the wyndowe, the Sceneſe commeth out.

div.head: Scena. v.
div.p: WOuld you ſpeake with me ſir?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yea ſir, I would faine knowe whence you are.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Sir I am a Sicilian, at your commaundement.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What part of Sicilia?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Of Cathanea.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What ſhall I call your name?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: My name is Philogano.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What trade doe you occupie?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Marchandiſe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What marchandiſe brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: None, I • ame onely to ſee a ſonne that I haue here whom I ſawe not theſe two yeares.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What call they your ſonne?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Is Eroſtrato your ſonne?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Yea verily.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And are you Philogano?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And a marchant of Cathanea?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: What néede I tell you ſo often? I will not tell you a lye.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yes, you haue told me a falſe lie, and thou arte a vilaine and no better.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Sir, you offer me great wrong with theſe iniurious wordes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Nay, I will doe more than I haue yet proffered to doe, for I will proue thée a lyer, and a knaue to take vpon thée that thou art not.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: A ſtoute ſuppoſe.Sir I am Philogano of Cathanea, out of all doubte, if I were not I would be loth to tell you ſo.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Oh, ſée the boldneſſe of this brute beaſt, what a braſen face he ſetteth on it?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Well, you may beleue me if you liſte: what wonder you?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I wonder at thy impudencie, for thou, nor nature that framed thée, can euer counterfaite thee to be me, ribauld villaine, and lying wretch that thou arte.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: A pleaſant ſuppoſe.Shall I ſuffer a knaue to abuſe my maiſters father thus? hence villaine, hence, or I will ſheath this good fawchiō in your paūch: if my maiſter Eroſtrato find you prating here on this faſhiō to his father, I wold not be in your coate for mo conney ſkins thā I gat theſe twelue monethes: come you in againe ſir, and let this Curre barke here till he burſt.

div.stage: Dalio pulleth the Sceneſe in at the dores.

div.head: Scena. vj.
div.p: LItio, how likeſt thou this géere?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Sir, I like it as euill as may be: but haue you not often heard tell of the falſehood of Ferara, and now may you ſée, it falleth out accordingly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Friend, you do not well to ſlaunder the Citie, theſe men are no Ferrareſes you may know by their tong.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Well, there is neuer a barrell better herring, béetwene you both: but in déed your officers are moſt to blame, that ſuffer ſuch faultes to eſcape vnpuniſhed.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: What knowe the officers of this? thinke you they know of euery fault?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Nay, I thinke they will knowe as little as may bée, ſpecially when they haue no gaines, by it, but they ought to haue their eares as open to heare of ſuch offēces, as the Ingates be to receiue gueſts.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Holde thy peace foole.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: By the maſſe I am a fearde that we ſhall be proued fooles both two.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Well, what ſhall we doe?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: I would thinke beſt we ſhould go ſéeke Eroſtrato him ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I will waite vpon you willingly, and either at the ſchooles, or at the conuocations, we ſhall find him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: By our Lady I am wery, I will run no longer about to ſeke him, I am ſure hither he will come at the laſt.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Sure,A true ſuppoſe. my mind giues me that we ſhall find a new Eroſtrato ere it be long.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Looke where he is, whether runnes he? ſtay you awhile, I will goe tell him that you are here: Eroſtrato, Eroſtraro, ho Eroſtrato, I would ſpeake with you.

div.stage: Eroſtrato is eſpied vppon the ſtage running about.

div.head: Scena. vij.
div.stage: Fained EROSTRATO. FERARESE. PHILOGANO. LITIO. DALIO.
div.p: NOwe can I hide me no longer. Alas what ſhall I doe: I will ſet a good face on, to beare out the matter.

sp.speaker: Fera.
sp.p: O Eroſtrato, Philogano your father is come out of Sicilia.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Tell me that I knowe not, I haue bene with him and ſéene him alredy.

sp.speaker: Fera.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? and it ſéemeth by him that you know not of his comming.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Why, haue you ſpoken with him? when ſaw you him I pray you?

sp.speaker: Fera.
sp.p: Loke you where he ſtandes, why go you not too him? Looke you Philogano, beholde your deare ſon Eroſtrato.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Eroſtrato? this is not Eroſtrato: thys ſéemeth rather to be Dulipo, and it is Dulipo in déede.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Why, doubte you of that?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: What ſaith this honeſt man?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Mary ſir, in deede you are ſo honorably • ladde, it is no maruell if you loke bigge.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: To whome ſpeaketh he?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What, God helpe, do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: As farre as I remember Sir, I neuer ſawe you before.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Harke Litio, h •• e is good géere, this honeſt man will not know me.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: A ſhameleſſe ſuppoſe.Gentleman, you take your markes amiſſe.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Did I not tell you of the falſehood of Ferrara maſter? Dulipo hath learned to play the knaue indifferently well ſince he came hither.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Peace I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Friend, my name is not Dulipo, aſke you thorough out this towne of great and ſmall, they know me: aſke this honeſt man that is with you, if you wyll not beléeue me.

sp.speaker: Ferra.
sp.p: In déede, I neuer knewe him otherwiſe called than Eroſtrato: and ſo they call him, as many as knowe him.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Maſter, nowe you may ſée the falſehood of theſe fellowes: this honeſt man your hoſte, is of counſaile with him,A needeleſſe ſuppoſe. and would face vs down that it is Eroſtrato: beware of theſe mates.

sp.speaker: Fera.
sp.p: Friende, thou doeſt me wrong to ſuſpect me, for ſure I neuer hearde hym otherwiſe called than Eroſtrato.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: What name could you heare me called by, but by my right name? But I am wiſe enough to ſtand prating here with this old man, I thinke he be mad.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Ah runnagate, ah villaine traitour, doeſt thou vſe thy maſter thus? what haſt thou done with my ſon villain?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Doth this dogge barke here ſtill? and will you ſuffer him maſter thus to reuile you?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Come in, come in, what wilt thou do with thys peſtil?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I will rap the olde cackabed on the coſterd.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Away with it, & you ſirra, lay downe theſe ſtones: come in at dore euery one of you, beare with him for his age, I paſſe not of his euill wordes.

div.stage: Eroſtrato taketh all his ſeruantes in at the dores.

div.head: Scena. viij.
div.p:
ALas, who ſhall relieue my miſerable eſtate? to whome ſhall I complaine? ſince he whome I brought vp of a childe, yea and cheriſhed him as if he had bene mine owne, doth nowe vtterly denie to knowe me: and you whome I toke for an honeſt man, and he that ſhould haue broughte me to the ſighte of my ſonne, are compacte with this falſe wretch, and woulde face me downe that he is Eroſtrato. An other ſuppoſe. Alas, you might haue ſome compaſſion of mine age, to the miſerie I am now in, and that I am a ſtranger deſolate of all comforte in this countrey: or at the leaſt, you ſhoulde haue
feared the vengeaunce of God the ſupreme iudge (whiche knoweth the ſecrets of all harts) in hearing this falſe witneſſe with him, whome heauen and earth doe knowe to be Dulipo and not Eroſtrato.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: If there be many ſuch witneſſes in this coūtrey, men may go about to proue what they wil in cōtrouerſies here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Well ſir, you may iudge of me as it pleaſeth you: & how the matter commeth to paſſe I know not, but truly, euer ſince he came firſt hither, I haue knowen him by the name of Eroſtrato the ſonne of Philogano a Cathaneſe: nowe whether he be ſo in déede, or whether he be Dulipo, (as you alledge) let that be proued by them that knewe him before he came hether. But I proteſt before God, that whiche I haue ſaid, is neither a matter compact with him, nor any other, but euen as I haue hard him called & reputed of al mē.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Out and alas, he whom I ſent hither with my ſon to be his ſeruaunt,A ſhrewde ſuppoſe. and to giue attendance on him, hath eyther cut his throate, or by ſome euill meanes made him away: and hath not onely taken his garmentes, his bookes, his money, and that whiche he brought out of Sicilia with him, but vſurpeth his name alſo, and turneth to his owne commoditie the bills of exchaunge that I haue alwayes allowed for my ſonnes expences. Oh miſerable Philogano, oh vnhappie old man: oh eternall God, is there no iudge? no officer? no higher powers whom I may complaine vnto for redreſſe of theſe wrongs?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Yes ſir, we haue poteſtates, we haue Iudges, and aboue al, we haue a moſt iuſte prince: doubt you not, but you ſhall haue iuſtice if your cauſe be iuſt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Bring me then to the Iudges, to the poteſtates, or to whome you thinke beſt: for I will diſcloſe a packe of the greateſt knauerie, a fardell of the fowleſt falſehoode that euer was heard of.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
Sir, he that wil goe to the lawe, muſt be ſure of foure things: firſt, a right and a iuſt cauſe: then a righteous aduocate
to pleade: nexte, fauour coram Iudice: and aboue all, a good purſe to procure it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I haue not heard, that the law hath any reſpect to fauour: what you meane by it I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Haue you no regard to his wordes, he is but a foole.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I pray you ſir, let him tell me what is fauour.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Fauour cal I, to haue a friend néere about the iudge, who may ſo ſollicite thy cauſe, as if it be right, ſpéedie ſentence may enſue without any delayes: if it be not good, then to prolong it, till at the laſt, thine aduerſarie being wearie, ſhalbe glad to compound with thée.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Of thus much (although I neuer heard thus muche in this coūtrey before) doubt you not Philogano, I will bring you to an aduocate that ſhall ſpéede you accordingly.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Then ſhall I giue my ſelfe, as it were a pray to the Lawyers, whoſe inſatiable iawes I am not able to féede, although I had here all the goods and landes which I poſſeſſe in mine own countrey: much leſſe being a ſtraunger in this miſerie. I know their cautels of old: at the firſt time I come they wil ſo extoll my cauſe, as though it were already won: but within a ſeuēnight or ten daies, if I do not continually féede them as the crow doth hir brattes, twētie times in an houre, they will begin to waxe colde, and to finde cauils in my cauſe, ſaying, that at the firſte I did not well inſtructe them, till at the laſt, they will not onely drawe the ſtuffing out of my purſe, but the marrow out of my bones.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Yea ſir, but this man that I tell you of, is halfe a Saincte.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: And the other halfe a Deuill, I hold a pennie.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Well ſayd Litio, in déede I haue but ſmal confidence in their ſmothe lookes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Well ſir, I thinke this whom I meane, is no ſuche manner of man: but if he were,An other ſuppoſe. there is ſuch hatred and euil wil betwene him & this gentlemā (whether he be Eroſtrato or Dulipo, what ſo euer he be) that I warrant you, he will
doe whatſoeuer he can do for you, were it but to ſpite him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why? what hatred is betwixt them?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: They are both in loue and ſuters to one gentlewoman, the daughter of a welthie man in this citie.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why? is the villeine become of ſuch eſtimatiō that he dare preſume to be a ſuter to any gentlewomā of a good familie?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Yea ſir out of all doubt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How call you his aduerſarie?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Cleander, one of the excellenteſt doctors in our citie.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: For Gods loue let vs goe to him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Goe we then.

div.head: Scena. 1.
div.p: WHat a miſhappe was this? that before I could méete with Eroſtrato, I haue light euen ful in the lap of Philogano: where I was cōſtrained to denie my name, to denie my maſter, & to faine that I knew him not, to contend with him, & to reuile him, in ſuch ſort, that hap what hap can, I cā neuer hap well in fauour with him againe. Therefore if I could come to ſpeake with ye right Eroſtrato, I will renounce vnto him both habite and credite, and away as faſt as I can trudge into ſome ſtrange countrey, where I may neuer ſee Philogano againe. Alas, he that of a litle childe hath brought me vp vnto this day,Another ſuppoſe. and nouriſhed me as if I had bene his owne: & in déede (to confeſſe the trouth) I haue no father to truſt vnto but him. But looke where Paſiphilo commeth, the fitteſt man in the world to goe on me meſſage to Eroſtrato.
div.stage: Eroſtrato eſpieth Paſiphilo comming towards him.

div.head: Scena. ij.
div.p:
TWo good newes haue I heard to day alreadie: one that Eroſtrato prepared a great feaſt this night: the other, that
he ſéeketh for me. And I to eaſe him of his trauaile, leaſt he ſhoulde runne vp and downe ſéeking me, and bicauſe no man loueth better thā I to haue an erand where good chéere is, come in poſt haſt euen home to his owne houſe: and loke where he is.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Paſiphilo, thou muſte doe one thing for me if thou loue me.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: If I loue you not, who loues you? commaunde me.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Go then a litle there, to Damons houſe, aſke for Dulipo, and tell him.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Wot you what? I cannot ſpeake with him, he is in priſon.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: In priſon? how commeth that to paſſe? where is he in priſon?

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: In a vile dungeon there within his maſters houſe.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Canſt thou tell wherefore?

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Be you content to know he is in priſon, I haue told you to muche.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: If euer you will doe any thing for me, tell me.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: I pray you deſire me not, what were you the better if you knew?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: More than thou thinkeſt Paſiphilo by God.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Well, and yet it ſtandes me vpon more than you thinke, to kéepe it ſecrete.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Why Paſiphilo, is this the truſt I haue had in you? are theſe the faire promiſes you haue awayes made me?

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: By the maſſe I would I had faſted this night with maiſter doctor, rather than haue come hither.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Wel Paſiphilo, eyther tel me, or at few woordes neuer thinke to be welcome to this houſe from henceforthe.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Nay, yet I had rather léeſe all the Gentlemen in this towne. But if I tell you any thing that diſpleaſe you, blame no body but your ſelfe now.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p:
There is nothing cā greue me more thā Dulipoes miſhappe, no not mine owne: and therfore I am ſure thou
canſt tell me no worſſe tidings.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Another plain and homely ſuppoſe.Well, ſince you would néedes haue it, I wil tell you: he was taken a bed with your beloued Polyneſta.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Alas, and doth Damon knowe it?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: An olde trotte in the houſe diſcloſed it to him, whervpon he tooke bothe Dulipo and the Nurſe which hath bene the broker of all this bargayne, and clapte them bothe in a cage, where I thinke they ſhall haue ſorowe ſoppes too their ſwéete meates.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Paſiphilo, go thy wayes into the kitchin, commaund the cooke to boyle and roaſt what liketh thee beſt, I make thée ſupra viſour of this ſupper.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By the maſſe if you ſhould haue ſtudied this ſeuennight, you could not haue appointed me an office to pleaſe me better. You ſhall ſée what diſhes I will deuiſe.

div.head: Scena. iij.
div.p:
I Was glad to rid him out of the way, leaſt he ſhoulde ſée me burſt out of theſe ſwelling teares, which hitherto with great payne I haue priſoned in my breſt, & leaſt he ſhoulde heare the Eccho of my doubled ſighes, whiche bounce from the botome of my heuy heart. O curſed I, O cruell fortune, that ſo many diſperſed griefes as were ſufficient to ſubuert a legion of Louers, haſt ſodenly aſſembled within my carefull carkaſe to treat this fearfull heart in ſunder with deſperation. Thou that haſt kepte my maſter all his youthe within the realme of Sicilia, reſeruing the wind and waues in a temperate calme (as it were at his commaunde) nowe to conuey his aged limmes hither, neither ſooner nor later: but euen in the worſt time that may be. If at any time before thou haddeſt conducted him, this enterpriſe had bene cut off without care in the beginning: and if neuer ſo little longer thou hadſt lingred his iorney, this happie day might
then haue fully finiſhed our drifts & deuiſes. But alas, thou haſt brought him euen in the very worſt time, to plunge vs al in the pit of perdition. Neither art thou content to entā gle me alone in thy ruinous ropes, but thou muſt alſo catch the right Eroſtrato in thy crooked clawes, to reward vs both with open ſhame & rebuke. Two yéeres haſt thou kept ſecrete our ſubtill Suppoſes, euen this day to diſcipher them with a ſorowfull ſucceſſe. What ſhall I do? Alas what ſhift ſhall I make? it is too late now to imagine any further deceite, for euery minute ſéemeth an houre til I find ſome ſuccour for the miſerable captiue Eroſtrato. Wel, ſince there is no other remedie, I wil go to my maſter Philogano, & to him will I tell the whole truth of the matter, that at the leaſt he may prouide in time, before his ſonne féele the ſmart of ſome ſharpe reuenge and puniſhment. This is the beſt, and thus wil I do. Yet I know, that for mine owne parte I ſhal do bitter penance for my faults forepaſſed: but ſuche is the good will and duetie that I beare to Eroſtrato, as euen with the loſſe of my life I muſt not ſticke to aduenture any thing which may turne to his commoditie. But what ſhall I do? ſhal I go ſéeke my maſter about the towne, or ſhall I tarrie his returne hither? If I méete him in the ſtréetes, he wil crie out vpon me, neither will he harken to any thing that I ſhall ſay, till he haue gathered all the people wondring about me, as it were at an Owle. Therefore I were better to abide here, and yet if he tarrie long I will goe ſéeke him, rather than prolong the time to Eroſtratos perill.

div.head: Scena. iiij.
div.p: YEa dreſſe them, but lay them not to the fire, till they will be ready to ſit downe. This géere goeth in order: but if I had not gone in, there had fallen a foule faulte.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: And what fault I pray thée?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Marie, Dalio would haue layd the ſhoulder of mutton and the Capon bothe to the fire at once like a foole: he did not conſider, that the one woulde haue more roaſting than the other.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Alas, I would this were the greateſt fault.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why? and either the one ſhould haue bene burned before the other had bene roaſted, or elſe he muſte haue drawne them off the ſpitte: and they would haue bene ſerued to the boorde either colde or rawe.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Thou haſt reaſon Paſiphilo.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Now ſir, if it pleaſe you I will goe into the towne and buye oranges, oliues, and caphers, for without ſuche ſauce the ſupper were more than halfe loſt.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Eroſtrato exit.There are within already, doubt you not, there ſhal lacke nothing that is neceſſarie.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Since I told him theſe newes of Dulipo, he is cleane beſide himſelf: he hath ſo many hammers in his head, that his braynes are ready to burſt:A knauiſhe ſuppoſe. and let them breake, ſo I may ſuppe with him to night, what care I? But is not this Dominus noſter Cleandrus that commeth before? well ſayde, by my truth we will teache maiſter Doctor to weare a cornerd cappe of a new faſhion. By God Polyneſta ſhal be his, he ſhall haue hir out of doubt, for I haue tolde Eroſtrato ſuch newes of hir, that he will none of hir.

div.stage: Cleander and Philogano come in, talking of the matter in controuerſie.

div.head: Scena. v.
div.p: YEa, but howe will ye proue that he is not Eroſtrato, hauing ſuch preſumptiōs to the cōtrarie? or how ſhall it be thought that you are Philogano, when an other taketh vpon him this ſame name, and for proofe bringeth him for a witneſſe, which hath bene euer reputed here for Eroſtrato?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
I will tel you ſir, let me be kept here faſt in priſon, &
at my charges let there be ſome man ſent into Sicilia, that may bring hither with him two or thrée of the honeſteſt mē in Cathanea, and by them let it be proued if I or this other be Philogano, and whether he be Eroſtrato or Dulipo my ſeruant: & if you finde me contrarie, let me ſuffer death for it.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I will go ſalute maſter Doctour.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: It will aſke great labour & great expences to proue it this way, but it is the beſt remedie that I can ſee.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: God ſaue you ſir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And reward you as you haue deſerued.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Then ſhall he giue me your fauour continually.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He ſhall giue you a halter, knaue and villein that thou arte.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I knowe I am a knaue, but no villein. I am your ſeruaunt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I neither take thée for my ſeruāt, nor for my friend.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why? wherein haue I offended you ſir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hence to the gallowes knaue.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What ſofte and faire ſir, I pray you, I praeſequar, you are mine elder.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I will be euen with you, be you ſure, honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why ſir? I neuer offended you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, I will teach you: out of my ſight knaue.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What? I am no dogge, I would you wiſt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Prateſt thou yet villein? I will make thée.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What will you make me? I ſée wel the more a man doth ſuffer you, the worſſe you are.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ah villein, if it were not for this gentleman, I wold tell you what I.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Villein? nay I am as honeſt a man as you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thou lieſt in thy throate knaue.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O ſir, ſtay your wiſedome.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: What will you fight? marie come on.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well knaue, I will méete with you another time, goe your way.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Euen when you liſt ſir, I will be your man.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And if I be not euen with thee, call me out.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Nay by the Maſſe, all is one, I care not, for I haue nothing: if I had either landes or goods, peraduenture you would pull me into the lawe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Sir, I perceiue your pacience is moued.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: This villaine: but let him goe, I will ſee him puniſhed as he hath deſerued. Now to the matter, how ſaid you?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Lawyers are neuer weary to get money.This fellow hath diſquieted you ſir, peraduenture you would be loth to be troubled any further.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Not a whit, ſay on, & let him go with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I ſay, let them ſend at my charge to Cathanea.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yea I remember that wel, & it is the ſureſt way as this caſe requireth: but tel me, how is he your ſeruant? and how come you by him? enforme me fully in the matter.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I will tell you ſir: when the Turkes won Otranto.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Oh, you put me in remembrance of my miſhappes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: For I was driuen among the reſt out of the towne (it is my natiue countrey) and there I loſt more than euer I ſhall recouer againe while I liue.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Alas, a pitifull caſe by S. Anne.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, procéede.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: At that time (as I ſaide) there were certaine of our countrey that ſcoured thoſe coſtes vpon the ſeas, with a good barke; well appointed for the purpoſe, and had eſpiall of a Turkey veſſell that came laden from thence with great aboundance of riches.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A gentle ſuppoſe.And peraduenture moſt of mine.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
So they boarded them, & in the end ouercame them, & brought the goods to Palermo,
〈◊〉 whence they came, and amōgſt other things that they had, was this villeine my ſeruaunt, a boy at that time, I thinke not paſt fiue yéeres olde.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Alas, I loſt one of that ſame age there.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
And I beyng there, and liking the Childes fauour
well, proffered them foure and twentie ducates for him, and had him.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What? was the childe a Turke? or had the Turkes brought him from Otranto?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: They ſaide he was a Childe of Otranto, but what is that to the matter? once .xxiiij. Ducattes he coſt me, that I wot well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Alas, I ſpeake it not for that ſir, I woulde it were he whome I meane.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why, whom meane you ſir?A crafty ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Beware ſir, be not to lauiſh.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Was his name Dulipo then? or had he not another name?

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Beware what you ſay ſir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What the deuill haſt thou to doe? Dulipo? no ſir his name was Carino.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Yea, well ſaid, tell all and more to, doe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O Lord, if it be as I thinke, how happie were I? & why did you change his name then?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: We called him Dulipo, bycauſe when he cryed as Chrildren doe ſometimes, he woulde alwayes cry on that name Dulipo.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, then I ſée well it is my owne onely Childe, whome I loſte, when I loſte my countrie: he was named Carino after his grandfather, and this Dulipo whome he alwayes remembred in his lamenting, was his foſter father that nouriſhed him and brought him vp.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Sir, haue I not told you enough of ye falſhood of Ferara? this gentleman will not only picke your purſe, but beguile you of your ſeruaunt alſo, & make you beleue he is his ſon.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well goodfellow, I haue not vſed to lie.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Sir no, but euery thing hath a beginning.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Fie, Philogano haue you not the leaſt ſuſpecte that may be of me.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p:
No marie, but it were good he had the moſt ſuſpecte
that may be.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, hold thou thy peace a litle good follow. I pray you tell me Philogano had ye child any remembrance of his fathers name, his mothers name, or ye name of his familie?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: He did remember them, and could name his mother alſo, but ſure I haue forgotten the name.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: I remember it well enough.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Tell it then.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Nay, that I will not marie, you haue tolde him too much al ready.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Tell it I ſay, if thou can.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Cā? yes by ye maſſe I cā wel enough: but I wil haue my tong pulled out, rather thā tell it, vnleſſe he tell it firſt: doe you not perceiue ſir, what he goeth about?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, I will tell you then, my name you know alredy: my wife his mothers name was Sophronia, the houſe that I came of, they call Spiagia.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: I neuer heard him ſpeake of Spiagia but in déede I haue heard him ſay, his mothers name was Sophronia: but what of yt? a great matter I promiſe you. It is like enoughe that you two haue compact together to deceiue my maiſter.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What nedeth me more euident tokens? this is my ſonne out of doubt whom I loſt eighteen yeares ſince, and a thouſand thouſand times haue I lamented for him: he ſhuld haue alſo a mould on his left ſhoulder.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: He hath a moulde there in deede: and an hole in an other place to, I would your noſe were in it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Faire wordes fellow Litio: oh I pray you let vs goe talke with him, O fortune, howe much am I bounde to thée if I finde my ſonne?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yea how little am I beholdē to fortune, that know not where my ſonne is become, and you whome I choſe to be mine aduocate, will nowe (by the meanes of this Dulipo) become mine aduerſarie?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
A right ſuppoſe.Sir, let vs firſt goe find mine: and I warrant you
yours will be founde alſo ere it be long.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: God graunt: goe we then,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Since the dore is open, I will neuer knocke nor cal, but we will be bolde to goe in.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Sir, take you héede, leaſt he leade you to ſome miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Alas Litio, if my ſonne be loſte what care I what become of me?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Well, I haue tolde you my minde Sir, doe you as you pleaſe.

stage.hi: Exeunt: Damon and Pſiteria come in.

div.head: Scena ſexta.
div.p: COme hither you olde kallat, you tatling huſwife, that the deuill cut oute your tong: tell me, howe could Paſiphilo know of this géere but by you?

sp.speaker: Pſi.
sp.p: Sir, he neuer knewe it of me, he was the firſte that tolde me of it.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Thou lieſt old drabbe, but I would aduiſe you tel me the truth, or I wil make thoſe old bones rattle in your ſkin.

sp.speaker: Pſi.
sp.p: Sir, if you finde me contrarie, kill me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why? where ſhould he talke with thée?

sp.speaker: Pſi.
sp.p: He talked with me of it here in the ſtreete.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What did you here?

sp.speaker: Pſi.
sp.p: I was going to the weauers for a webbe of clothe you haue there.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And what cauſe coulde Paſiphilo haue to talke of it, vnleſſe thou began the mater firſt?

sp.speaker: Pſi.
sp.p: Nay, he began with me ſir, reuiling me, bycauſe I had tolde you of it: I aſked him how he knewe of it, and he ſaid he was in the ſtable when you examined me ere while.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Alas, alas, what ſhall I doe then? in at dores olde whore, I wil plucke that tong of thine out by the rootes one day. Alas it gréeueth me more that Paſiphilo knoweth it,
than all the reſt. He that will haue a thing kept ſecrete, let him tell it to Paſiphilo: the people ſhall knowe it, and as many as haue eares and no mo. By this time he hath tolde it in a hundreth places. Cleander was the firſte, Eroſtrato the ſeconde, and ſo from one to another throughout the citie. Alas, what dower, what mariage ſhall I nowe prepare for my daughter? O poore dolorons Damon, more miſerable than miſerie it ſelfe,The firſt ſuppoſe brought to concluſion. would God it were true that Polyneſta tolde me ere while: that he who hathe deflowred hir, is of no ſeruile eſtate, (as hitherto he hath bene ſuppoſed in my ſeruice) but that he is a gentleman borne of a good parentage in Sicilia. Alas, ſmall riches ſhoulde content me, if he be but of an honeſt familie: but I feare that he hathe deuiſed theſe toyes to allure my daughters loue. Well I wil goe examine hir againe, my minde giueth me that I ſhall perceiue by hir tale whether it be true or not. But is not this Paſiphilo that cōmeth out of my neighbours houſe? what the deuill ayleth him to leape and laughe ſo like a foole in ye high way?

div.stage: Paſiphilo commeth out of the towne laughing.

div.head: Scena ſeptima.
div.p: O God, that I might finde Damon at home.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What the diuill would he with me?

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: That I may be the firſte that ſhall bring him theſe newes.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What will he tell me, in the name of God?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: O Lord, how happie am I? loke where he is.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What newes Paſiphilo, that thou arte ſo merie?

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Sir I am mery to make you glad: I bring you ioyfull newes.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And that I haue nede of Paſiphilo.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p:
I knowe ſir, that you are a ſorowfull man for this miſhap that hath chaunced in your houſe, peraduenture you thoughte I had not knowen of it. But let it paſſe, plucke vp
your ſprits, and reioyce: for he that hath done you this iniurie is ſo well borne, and hath ſo riche parents, that you may be glad to make him your ſonne in law.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: How knoweſt thou?

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: His father Philogano one of the worthieſt men in all Cathanea, is nowe come to the citie, and is here in your neighbours houſe.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, in Eroſtratos houſe?

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Nay in Dulipos houſe: for where you haue alwayes ſuppoſed this gentlemā to be Eroſtrato, it is not ſo, but your ſeruaunt whom you haue empriſoned hitherto, ſuppoſed to be Dulipo, he is in dede Eroſtrato: and that other is Dulipo. And thus they haue alwayes, euen ſince their firſt ariual in this citie, exchaunged names, to the ende that Eroſtrato the maiſter, vnder ye name of Dulipo a ſeruant, might be entertained in your houſe, & ſo winne the loue of your daughter.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Wel, then I perceiue it is euē as Polineſta told me.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Why, did ſhe tell you ſo?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yea: But I thought it but a tale.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Well, it is a true tale: and here they will be with you by and by: both Philogano this worthie man, and maiſter doctor Cleander.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Cleander? what to doe?

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p: Cleander? Why therby lies another tale, the moſte fortunate aduenture that euer you heard: wot you what? this other Dulipo, whome all this while we ſuppoſed to be Eroſtrato, is founde to be the ſonne of Cleander, whome he loſt at the loſſe of Otranto, and was after ſolde in Sicilia too this Philogano the ſtrangeſt caſe that euer you heard: a mā might make a Comedie of it. They wil come euen ſtraight, and tell you the whole circumſtance of it themſelues.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay I will firſt goe heare the ſtorie of this Dulipo, be it Dulipo or Eroſtrato that I haue here within, before I ſpeake with Philogano.

sp.speaker: Paſ.
sp.p:
So ſhall you doe well ſir, I will goe tell them that
they may ſtay a while, but loke where they come.
